newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Coconut Oil - Market seen sluggish due to festivals.
newsitem.headline: Coconut Oil - Market seen sluggish due to festivals.

text.p: Coconut oil prices are expected to stay in a narrow range this week ahead of the Chinese New Year and the Moslem Eid-ul-Fitr, Philippine vegetable oil traders said on Monday.
"I expect a lull this week," said a senior trader in one of the country's largest coconut oil millers.
The trader said he expected prices to hold at current levels, or at $760 to $800 per tonne CIF due to tight supplies.

Philippine coconut oil exports in January this year reached 85,000 tonnes from the year-ago 74,074 tonnes, trade group United Coconut Association of the Philippines Inc (UCAP) said on Monday citing preliminary data.
But Manila traders said coconut export numbers in January 1997 included a carry-over of up to 34,800 tonnes from December 1996 due to delayed ship loadings.

"There was a vessel, MV Luctor, that started loading December 30, 1996 and finished on January 3, 1997. So the volume of 29,000 tonnes was included in the January 1997 export figure," a senior trader in one of the country's largest oil millers said.
Another trader put the coconut oil cargo of MV Luctor at 30,800 tonnes.

Traders also said another ship, MV Sea Stort, that was supposed to carry a cargo of 4,000 tonnes of coconut oil in December 1996 was delayed. "The ship was able to load the coconut oil cargo last month," one trader said.
Traders said they expected tight Philippine supply of coconut oil to ease in April this year.
Last week, coconut oil prices softened by an average of $7 at $770 per tonne CIF in Rotterdam from the previous $777, UCAP said.
Traders attributed the slide due to fresh supplies from MV Blue Sapphire with a cargo of 20,000 tonnes and MV Auriga with another cargo of 16,000 tonnes.
"Fresh supplies of coconut oil from the Philippines boosted stocks in Rotterdam in the past two weeks," another trader said.
Coconut oil stocks in Rotterdan increased to 21,593 tonnes as of January 27 as against 20,732 tonnes on January 20.
